speaker: Roz
text: Faster, Frasier, faster! [_throws her leg across and stamps the accelerator_] You can make this light!

speaker: Frasier
text: God, you're going to get us killed!

speaker: Roz
text: I can't be late for this date!

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, this is ridiculous!  First the drycleaner, then the ATM, now you're making me cart you off to some restaurant!

speaker: Roz
text: Well, I'm sorry, I didn't plan for my car to be in the shop. But I really, really appreciate it, Frasier. [_starts unbuttoning her shirt_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, a basket of fruit would suffice!

speaker: Roz
text: I am changing for my date!  Don't look at me!  Turn around! Turn all the way around!

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm driving!

speaker: Roz
text: Fine! [_climbs into the backseat_] Hand me my jeans, will you?

speaker: Frasier
text: Here. [_hands them to her, then checks the rearview_] Oh, oh, great!  There's a police car behind us.  Please don't turn on the red light.  Don't turn on the red light.  Don't turn on the--

speaker: Roz
text: Damn it, Frasier!  Don't worry, you're not going to get a ticket.  You're a celebrity, use a little juice!

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, I refuse to do anything of the sort!

speaker: Roz
text: OK, fine.  Enjoy traffic school.

speaker: Frasier
text: Hello, officer.  I'm listening. _The cop -- an attractive red-haired woman -- bends down, all business. _

speaker: Cop
text: I clocked you doing sixty-two in a forty-mile zone.  _She shines her flashlight in the backseat.  Roz, still half out of her jeans, waves sheepishly._

speaker: Cop
text: Well, this is interesting.  Usually both people are in the backseat.

speaker: Frasier
text: It's not what you think.  See, we were just coming back from KACL, where I do my radio show.

speaker: Cop
text: Uh-huh.

speaker: Frasier
text: You see, we ran a little late, because I was on with a very troubled caller, with a very complex psychological problem... on my radio show.

speaker: Cop
text: Hey, wait a minute.  You're Dr. Frasier Crane!

speaker: Frasier
text: Drat!  My cover is blown.

speaker: Cop
text: I love your show!  I listen to it all the time.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh well, thank you.  It's always nice to--

speaker: Cop
text: License and registration, please.

speaker: Frasier
text: Be arrested by a fan. _He hands them over.  Roz, who has not halted her pre-date preparation, leans forward to the rearview mirror and sprays perfume on her neck._

speaker: Frasier
text: Roz, if you could delay ablutions?  I'm in custody here!

speaker: Cop
text: Hey, it's your birthday today. [_re: Roz_] Is this a little celebration?

speaker: Frasier
text: No, no, I'm simply taking my producer to meet her date.

speaker: Roz
text: Frasier, why didn't you tell me it was your birthday?  I'd have thrown you a party at the station!

speaker: Frasier
text: Question asked, question answered. [_to cop_] I'm just going to be dropping her off, then have a cold plate of deli, and get to bed early.  Almost makes you feel sorry for me, doesn't it?

speaker: Cop
text: I spent my last birthday subduing a drunk-and-disorderly at a sleazy bar.

speaker: Frasier
text: Don't you hate to work on your birthday?

speaker: Cop
text: He was my date.  Tell you what I'm going to do.  I'm going to let you off. [_hands his license back_] Just think of this as a little birthday gift from me.

speaker: Frasier
text: Thank you.

speaker: Cop
text: But slow down.  I'd hate to see you get hurt.

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm listening.

speaker: Roz
text: OK, let's go!

speaker: Frasier
text: Do you sense a little moment there?

speaker: Roz
text: [_"Why are we not moving?!"_] What are you talking about?!

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, between me and that very attractive officer.  It just felt like there was something there.

speaker: Roz
text: Yeah, major sparks.  Now, just the right pedal.  The big pedal--

speaker: Frasier
text: Now, just a minute. [_adjusts the rearview_] We'll see if she's watching me.  If she's watching me, she's interested. Oh, yes!  She's turning around, she's looking up!

speaker: Cop
text: [_over bullhorn_] Move your vehicle!

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, yes.  I've cast my spell. _FADE OUT  Scene Two -- Apartment Frasier sits at the dinner table before a birthday cake.  Martin, Niles, and Daphne stand over him.  Eddie is in a chair._

speaker: Daphne
text: Go on, Dr. Crane, make a wish.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_making evil eyes at Eddie_] Oh, why bother?  I made the same wish last year, it didn't come true.

speaker: Martin
text: Come on, son, blow out the candles!  _Frasier draws breath, and blows out the candles, which promptly light again -- trick candles.  Daphne and Martin laugh, Niles applauds lightly._

speaker: Frasier
text: [_dry, sarcastic_] Oh, what a surprise.  Look, they're lighting again!  What sorcerer's magic is this? [_cuts the cake_] You know, Dad, I had a nice little birthday bonus today.  On my way home, I was pulled over for speeding by a very pretty policewoman, who let me off.  I got the distinct impression that she found me attractive.  Now, that sort of thing happens, doesn't it?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, sure.  I was always leaning against somebody's window thinking, "that bloody chainsaw in the backseat looks kind of iffy, but she's got a cute smile!"

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, ha, ha.  I'm telling you, there was something there, though.  Well, of course the whole conversation's academic. I don't even know her name.  I suppose I could call down to the police station and try to find out who was on traffic duty.  But, uh, I don't suppose they'd give that sort of information to a civilian.  You'd have to have some... conduit to the police department, an insider who could break that damnable code of silence!

speaker: Martin
text: All right, I'll make the damn call. [_goes to the phone_]

speaker: Frasier
text: You, Dad?  Why, I didn't even think of--

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, shut up.

speaker: Frasier
text: You know, I haven't felt such an instant attraction to a woman in quite some time.  Well, considering the difference in our backgrounds, it's really rather puzzling.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, pish-tosh!  It's painfully obvious what's attracting you -- the gleam of her jackboots, her dangling nightstick, the glint of her handcuffs hanging on her leather belt.  You're off on some lurid little disciplinary fantasy.

speaker: Daphne
text: [_notices_] Oh, Dr. Crane, shame on you!  You got icing up and down your sleeve!

speaker: Niles
text: Oh.  I am a naughty boy.

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, certainly a messy one.

speaker: Niles
text: But mainly a naughty one.

speaker: Martin
text: [_on phone_] Hey, Charlie, yeah, Marty Crane, how ya doing? Hey, listen, Charlie, I'm trying to track down a woman officer who was on traffic tonight, uh, near...

speaker: Frasier
text: Blanchett and Fourth.

speaker: Martin
text: Blanchett and Fourth.  Great, OK, thanks. [_hangs up_] Her name's Maureen Cutler, and she usually goes to McGinty's after work.  Charlie said she's probably there now.

speaker: Frasier
text: Thanks, Dad.

speaker: Martin
text: Are you going to go?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I don't know.  A police bar?  If I go in there alone, I'll stand out like a sore thumb!

speaker: Niles
text: All right, I'll go.

speaker: Martin
text: Sit down, Niles, I'll go with him.  You know, after all these hoity-toity, caviar-sucking egghead types you've been dating, I think a lady cop would be a nice breath of fresh air.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, all right, I'll go!  Give me a second, I'll put some fresh collar-stays in, and-oh, oh, I've got a fabulous brand-new cashmere jacket I've been dying to premiere!

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, yeah.  This is gonna work. **SINS OF THE FATHER**  _Scene Three -- McGinty's The bar is packed with off-duty cops and other working stiffs. Martin, dressed in a letterman jacket, stands next to Frasier, who stands out like a sore thumb in his suit._

speaker: Martin
text: You see her yet?

speaker: Frasier
text: I don't know.

speaker: Martin
text: [_pointing_] What about her?

speaker: Frasier
text: No, that's not Maureen.

speaker: Martin
text: No, I mean, what about _her_?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, there she is!  _The cop (Maureen), in casual dress, is standing over by the jukebox, joking with a friend._

speaker: Martin
text: Wow, she is a looker!  Well, come on, let's go say hello. _They go over.  As Maureen catches sight of them, Frasier smotes his forehead in feigned surprise._

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh well!  Oh my God, fancy seeing you here!

speaker: Maureen
text: Hey, Frasier Crane.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, you remember me?

speaker: Maureen
text: Come on -- sixty-two in a forty-mile zone with a half-naked girl in the backseat?

speaker: Frasier
text: Roz.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, uh, this is my father.

speaker: Maureen
text: How do you do?  I'm Maureen Cutler.

speaker: Martin
text: [_shaking hands_] Marty Crane, nice to meet you.

speaker: Maureen
text: Nice to meet you.

speaker: Martin
text: Say, Maureen, how about a drink?

speaker: Maureen
text: Yeah, why not?

speaker: Frasier
text: Let me get them.  I'm a beer drinker myself, what about you?

speaker: Maureen
text: That's fine by me.

speaker: Martin
text: Beer, huh?  Oh, what the hell, I'll try one.

speaker: Maureen
text: So, what brings you guys here?  This is mostly a cop hangout.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, I used to be on the force.

speaker: Maureen
text: Really?

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah.

speaker: Maureen
text: Wait a minute.  Marty Crane?  You're Martin Crane!

speaker: Martin
text: You're wasting your time in traffic, you're quite a detective. [_laughs_]

speaker: Maureen
text: No, I mean I remember you when I was training.  You gave this great lecture at the academy on how to deal with an armed suspect.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, thanks.

speaker: Maureen
text: How come you left the force?

speaker: Martin
text: Well, I uh, got shot by an armed suspect. [_laughs_]

speaker: Maureen
text: I'm sorry.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, it's all right.

speaker: Maureen
text: So, do you miss it?

speaker: Martin
text: Nah, how attached can you get to a hip?

speaker: Maureen
text: Oh.  Oh, I'm sorry. [_gets up_] I have to get over to the hospital.  I told them to beep me if there was any news about my sergeant.

speaker: Martin
text: What happened to him?

speaker: Maureen
text: She's having a baby.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh well, hope it's a girl!  Yeah, I'll tell Frasier you had to run.

speaker: Maureen
text: Thanks... listen, um, I never do this, but I would love to have a beer or go to dinner sometime.

speaker: Martin
text: [_taken aback_] With me?

speaker: Maureen
text: I don't want to put you on the spot. [_gives him her card_] If you, uh, if you want to go out, just give me a call.

speaker: Martin
text: With me?

speaker: Maureen
text: You're the only one here.

speaker: Frasier
text: Here we are!  Three beers.  Good news, there was a fly in one glass, so these are free!

speaker: Maureen
text: I'm sorry, I just got beeped.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, that's too bad.

speaker: Maureen
text: Yeah, but it was nice to see you.  Maybe I'll bump into you again here sometime.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, that'd be great.

speaker: Maureen
text: OK, bye.

speaker: Frasier
text: Bye.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I think that went very well, don't you?  _Martin is speechless.  END OF ACT ONE  ACT TWO  Scene Four -- Cafe Nervosa Niles is sitting at a corner table.  The Waitress takes his order._

speaker: Niles
text: I'll have a grande half-caf latte, with a whisper of cinnamon.  And for my father, plain coffee.  I cannot emphasize the word "plain" enough.  No foam, no cinnamon, no exotic flavors.  If it is not plain, I take no responsibility for the consequences.

speaker: Waitress
text: How about a biscotti?

speaker: Niles
text: All right.  But when you bring it, call it a cookie.

speaker: Martin
text: Hi, son.

speaker: Niles
text: Hello, Dad.

speaker: Martin
text: Uh, I want to thank you for meeting me like this.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, my pleasure. [_they sit_] So... what can I do you for?

speaker: Martin
text: Well, I need some advice.

speaker: Niles
text: That's why you asked me here?

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah.

speaker: Niles
text: You've never done this before!

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, well, I'm sorry.  But anyway, you remember--

speaker: Niles
text: Dad, I want you to know I'm not only deeply touched, but I consider this a watershed moment in our relationship!

speaker: Martin
text: Great.  See, the thing is--

speaker: Niles
text: All my life, it seems you've always turned to Frasier. "Frasier, Frasier, Frasier!"

speaker: Martin
text: Niles, can I talk?!

speaker: Niles
text: I'm listening.

speaker: Waitress
text: Here we are.  One latte, one coffee, and one [_looks at Niles_] "cookie."

speaker: Martin
text: I think they call this thing a biscotti.

speaker: Niles
text: No need to talk down to the man.  Off you go!

speaker: Martin
text: Well, anyway, uh, you remember the other night, Frasier's policewoman?

speaker: Niles
text: Mmm-hmm.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, we found her at the bar, and, uh, well, she came on to me.

speaker: Niles
text: No.

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah.

speaker: Niles
text: You?

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah.

speaker: Niles
text: Was she drunk? [_Martin glares_] Oh, I'm sorry, Dad, of course, you're right, I'm sorry.  Uh, [_barely able to contain his delight_] what was Frasier's reaction?

speaker: Martin
text: I haven't told him yet.

speaker: Niles
text: Why not?

speaker: Martin
text: I just can't.

speaker: Niles
text: Can I?

speaker: Martin
text: I know he's going to feel lousy.  He finally meets a girl he likes, and she's attracted to his old man.

speaker: Niles
text: Hmm, that is quite a conundrum.  I wonder if that's what's really bothering you.

speaker: Martin
text: What do you mean?

speaker: Niles
text: Maybe, underneath it all, you're attracted to this woman and you want to go out with her.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, are you, nuts?  That's sick!  That's disgusting!

speaker: Martin
text: But for the sake of argument, let's say you're right.

speaker: Niles
text: Dad, you're allowed to be attracted to a woman.

speaker: Martin
text: What kind of a father does a thing like that?

speaker: Niles
text: Did you encourage her in any way?

speaker: Martin
text: Well, I guess I was kind of charming.  I mean, I didn't mean to be!  It just sometimes leaks out.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, what do you want to do?

speaker: Martin
text: Well, most important I don't want to hurt Frasier.  And secondly, I want to go out with Maureen.  The order of that changes depending on the time of day.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, one possibility is, go on a date with her.  If you feel there are sparks between you and this woman, then tell Frasier.

speaker: Martin
text: I don't want to lie to my son.

speaker: Niles
text: You're not lying to him.  You're delaying the truth to spare his feelings.  If nothing happens, he need never know.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, I guess it's worth a try.  If Maureen and I hit it off, then I'll tell him immediately.

speaker: Niles
text: Or I can.  Really, I don't mind!  _Martin gives him a look.  FADE TO:  Scene Five -- Apartment Martin walks toward the door, looking around like a guilty teenager. Just as he reaches the door, Frasier comes out._

speaker: Frasier
text: Hi, Dad.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, Frasier!  You're still home.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yeah.  Where are you going?

speaker: Martin
text: Just out.

speaker: Frasier
text: What are you gonna do?

speaker: Martin
text: Nothing.

speaker: Frasier
text: When are you gonna be home?

speaker: Martin
text: Later.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, you put a dent in the car, young man, it's coming out of your allowance!  _Martin laughs weakly and leaves.  Frasier picks up a book and a glass of wine from the coffee table and takes them to the kitchen.  Daphne comes in the front door with Charlotte and Maggie -- two fellow domestic servants of British descent -- with shopping bags._

speaker: Charlotte
text: I mean, I've got my pride, you know.  So, I said to her, I said, "Mrs. Crease, I'll do the cooking, I'll do the cleaning, but I draw the line at creaming your feet!"

speaker: Charlotte
text: Dear, hurry up!  "The Mambo Kings" is about to start!

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, I wouldn't mind mamboing with Antonio Banderas! All right, set out the goodies and I'll go get the wine.  _As Daphne heads for the kitchen, Charlotte and Maggie put their feet up on the coffee table.  Charlotte unwraps a large chocolate bar._

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, and this time, Charlotte, be careful with that chocolate!  I had a hell of a time hiding the stain from His Nibs-- [_runs headlong into Frasier_] Oh, hello, Dr. Crane! _Charlotte and Maggie hide their goodies and jump to attention. Frasier smiles benevolently, enjoying the power of a man who knows exactly what's going on._

speaker: Frasier
text: Daphne.  Charlotte, Maggie.

speaker: Charlotte/Maggie
text: Dr. Crane.

speaker: Frasier
text: Please, sit down. [_they do_]

speaker: Daphne
text: I thought you were filling in at the station tonight.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, I am.  But, uh, not for a couple of hours yet. _He takes his book and wine to a chair, giving every sign of settling in.  Behind his back, Charlotte and Maggie mime "Get him out of here!" while Daphne mimes back helplessness._

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh-ho, seems a shame to hang around here.  I mean, I would have thought you'd have taken an opportunity like this to, I don't know... go down to McGinty's?

speaker: Charlotte
text: Oh, to see his new lady friend, you mean?

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah, well, I see I've been quite the hot topic over the teapot.

speaker: Daphne
text: You know, I may have said a thing or two in passing, but--

speaker: Charlotte
text: I'd go for it, Dr. Crane!

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, well, if you must know, I was planning to go down there, but not for a couple of days yet.

speaker: Charlotte
text: Well, I wouldn't wait too long.  I mean, strike while the iron's hot, that's what I always say!

speaker: Daphne
text: She's right.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, women don't really like men that are too overeager.

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, nonsense.  I mean, you know, it's one thing if the man's some bounder git from the docks, but it's different if the man's like you.

speaker: Maggie
text: Someone who's charming.

speaker: Charlotte
text: And handsome.

speaker: Daphne
text: And knows lots and lots of words.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, McGinty's is on my way to the station.  I suppose I could just pop my head in. [_picks up his briefcase and goes to the door_] Thank you, ladies, for your support -- even if it was nakedly self-serving and insincere.  _He smiles at them and leaves.  FADE TO:  Scene Six -- McGinty's Maureen and Martin are sitting at a table.  Martin's back is to the door._

speaker: Maureen
text: So, they finally put my transfer through, and I'm moving out of Traffic and into Narcotics.  Yeah, I'm gonna be working with, uh, Bill Henderson at the 31st.

speaker: Martin
text: Good for you.  _Frasier looks through the window.  Through the crowd, he sees Maureen, but not Martin._

speaker: Maureen
text: Yeah, I'm excited, although I hear he can be pretty tough.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh no.  I mean, he might seem a little stiff and strait-laced, but once you get to know him he's the greatest guy in the world.

speaker: Maureen
text: Yeah, he is pretty impressive.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh yeah, smart, great sense of humor.  No, you're gonna have a great time.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, I can't believe you're doing this!

speaker: Maureen
text: Frasier!

speaker: Martin
text: Look, I was gonna tell you--

speaker: Frasier
text: [_to Maureen_] Believe me, I did not put him up to this, though I think he's overselling me a little.  I'm not the greatest guy in the world.  Seattle, maybe.

speaker: Maureen
text: Am I missing something?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, I'm just joking.  OK, Dad, thanks for warming her up for me.  I can take over here.

speaker: Maureen
text: Martin?

speaker: Martin
text: Frasier... Maureen and I are here on a date.  _Frasier absorbs that.  Then he laughs jovially.  Holding up a "one second" finger, he takes Martin's drink and downs it in one gulp, turning his face away as a stormy expression crosses it._

speaker: Frasier
text: I know you might think this is one of those wildly embarrassing moments where I'm standing here with egg on my face.  I assure you, I'm not as embarrassed as you might assume I would be embarrassed.  I'm not uncomfortable, so please, don't you be uncomfortable either.

speaker: Maureen
text: [_getting up_] Why don't I give you two a moment?

speaker: Frasier
text: Whatever!

speaker: Frasier
text: You asked her out?!

speaker: Martin
text: No, that's not the way it happened.

speaker: Frasier
text: There's no use lying to me.  I am at the lowest point I could possibly be, so please just tell me the truth!

speaker: Martin
text: Maureen asked me out.

speaker: Frasier
text: Going down!

speaker: Martin
text: It happened the other night when you went to the bar to get drinks.  You know, it just caught me off guard, I didn't know how to handle it.  So, Niles said I should--

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles?  Niles knows?

speaker: Martin
text: Look, I'm sorry.  It was supposed to be a one-time thing, just to see if there was something there, and if there wasn't, then you didn't even need to know about it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, is there?  "Something there?"

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, yeah.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well... it's not as if we were standing side-by-side when she chose you.  I was at the bar!  If you'd gone to get the drinks, things would have been different.

speaker: Martin
text: I don't think so.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, I'm drowning here.  Please, throw me a line!

speaker: Martin
text: Look, uh, I'm gonna go tell her this whole thing is a mistake--

speaker: Frasier
text: No, no, no, Dad!  I'll be OK, really.  Well... the old dog's still got it in him, huh?

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah.  But, really, how long can it last?  I mean, she's got to come to her senses eventually--

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh no, Dad, Dad, don't sell yourself short.  You've got a lot to offer.  Well, I'd better head off to work. Goodnight, Dad.

speaker: Martin
text: Goodnight, thanks. _Frasier picks up his briefcase and heads to the door.  As Maureen goes back to the table, he can't resist turning back and letting out a:_

speaker: Frasier
text: Damn! **DOES THIS MEAN YOU WON'T DO MY TAXES, EDNA?**  _Scene Seven -- KACL Roz is talking on the phone in her booth.  A dozen staffers crowd around her._

speaker: Roz
text: Uh-uh, OK, thanks. [_hangs up_] Frasier just came in the building, so everybody hide and be quiet.

speaker: Betty
text: Do you think he'll be surprised?

speaker: Roz
text: Considering his birthday was yesterday?  Yeah, I do, Elizabeth.

speaker: Betty
text: Should we yell "surprise" or "happy birthday?"

speaker: Roz
text: We've done this like five hundred times.  And every time it's pretty much the same.  We yell, the person pretends to be surprised, and we stuff ourselves with cake.

speaker: Betty
text: I just wanted it to be perfect.

speaker: Roz
text: And that is what makes you so special to us.  Now get under the console!  _The staffers huddle under the console.  Roz goes into the other booth and opens the door to Frasier._

speaker: Roz
text: Hi, Frasier! [_he grunts_] How you doing?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, just wonderful.  Forty-three is off to a rousing start. Remember that policewoman I was interested in?

speaker: Roz
text: Yeah?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, she's dating my father!

speaker: Roz
text: Your father?

speaker: Frasier
text: Mmm-hmm!

speaker: Roz
text: Well, never mind that.  I know just what will take your mind off of it.  I've got something really funny in my booth.

speaker: Frasier
text: I spent the last hour wandering the streets, trying to take assessment of my life.  Do you know how long it's been since I've slept with a woman?  Seven months!

speaker: Roz
text: Frasier--

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, nine months!

speaker: Roz
text: I really don't think we should talk about that right now!  _She closes the connecting door, ignoring the protesting motions of the staffers._

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh sure, fine, you can't spare me five minutes to talk about my problems, when every day I drop what I'm doing to be your personal Wailing Wall. "Frasier, he stopped calling me." "Frasier, he wants his key back."  "Frasier, his girlfriend is having me followed!"

speaker: Roz
text: I'm sorry.

speaker: Roz
text: So nine months, huh?

speaker: Frasier
text: Nine long, long, months.

speaker: Roz
text: Oh...

speaker: Frasier
text: You know who that woman was?

speaker: Roz
text: Who?

speaker: Frasier
text: Edna, from Accounting.

speaker: Roz
text: No...

speaker: Frasier
text: The next day, she dumped me!  I tell you, Roz, I'm starting to feel nostalgic for that summer in my twenties when I was impotent!

speaker: Frasier
text: The only comfort I have now is knowing that my humiliation can't possibly get any worse!

speaker: Staffers
text: [_jumping up_] SURPRISE! _Frasier looks around, realizing the scope of his disclosure - then he notices one female staffer staring at him dourly._

speaker: Frasier
text: Hi, Edna. _FADE OUT  END OF ACT TWO_
